title: It's been a couple of weeks since Vel'koz was buffed, and his win rate has not moved
body:
And this is no surprise to anyone who mains Vel'koz, because the buff given to him **made absolutely no sense.**

Can we please have some accountability for dumb changes like this? It's literally someone's job to figure out what changes are needed to bring champions to a good place, and it's clear that they just threw in a bigger number without analyzing or understanding anything about the champion. 

Someone is not doing their job.

replies.body: Vel'Koz is only really weak because of the champions he's facing up against. Too many assassins that he struggles to play against, and given how much the community is pressuring Riot to look into nerfing assassins it might be a poor idea to buff him, considering he may be too strong afterwards

I believe Riot have unintentionally shot themselves in the foot with how they have treated mages this season.

It feels as though mages are the class that fit best into how a MOBA is meant to be played. Whilst a lot of people are complaining about this 'high damage assassin/fighter' meta, others metas are equally as fun. Tanks metas where a Maokai just sticks on top of you for 20 seconds a slowly whittling you to death is no fun either and neither is an ADC 4 hitting every champion in the game, whilst being almost impossible to take down, because their enchanter support, who is inevitably also meta at this time, just heals and shields them for 1,000 extra damage is fun either.

Mages feel different though. Aside from the rare exceptions such as {{champion:8}} and {{champion:268}} they really feel like a class that's overall really well balanced. Their damage is very obvious. Either they're high range skill shots, that will rarely kill you in one hit, or short range point and click abilities. Both of which have obvious strengths and weaknesses. Oh, you're laning against {{champion:161}} ? Make sure not to be hit by his e, or take too much poke damage from his q and you should be fine! Laning against an {{champion:1}} ? No problems, just make sure to stay out of her range and you shouldn't have any problems. 

And unlike a fed fighter or assassin, the game doesn't feel like it's over if a mage gets ahead. They simply don't have the mobility or durability to allow them to make the same mistakes that other classes can make. Get the pick on a mage who's out of position and they are unlikely going to live, no matter how fed they are. 

On the flip side, if a mage falls behind, it doesn't feel like they're completely useless either. Would you rather have an 0/8 LeBlanc who can't even one shot the enemy Sona or an 0/8 Annie? Neither of them are ideal team mates but one of them still has the potential to land a huge AoE stun than can win a team fight of even the game despite being put off to an early start. Not to mention, a lot of them have pick based abilities that will allow their team to dish out the damage they may not provide, such as Lux's Q and Xerath's E. 

TL;DR - I believe mages should be the focal point of every team as it feels like they have clear cut strengths and weaknesses vs every class in the game, a trait no other class shares.

Very true. It might be a weird comparison but look at Vel Koz and Atrox: Vel uses his E - it is announced, your enemy sidesteps and he knows he's save from your combo and your passive. Then there's Aatrox - you see the hitbox, you sidestep.... And then he can dash mid skill to actually change the hitbox and opposed to Vel Koz's Q there is essentially no announcement for the near instant hitbox adjustment. Not to mention Vel's Q being blocked by creeps and hitbox size. To stick with Aatrox as an example - we have reached a point where the range squishy mages like Vel Koz have on their QWE isn't paid for in lack of durability (when creating new champions) anymore. These days even melees get poke abilities with similar or higher range than mages! (On lower cooldown...manaless)


Riot is just overloading new / reworked champions' kits so much that anybody who doesn't have a low CD dash to avoid getting gibbed - or is faster at gibbing - is near useless. This hurts combo mages like Vel Koz particularly hard - because that's one of the reasons why every new champion gets multiple dashes and hitting your combo becomes harder with each patch.

Is this an actual quote or did you make it up?

It's taken out of context and twisted a bit. [Here's Ghostcrawler's explanation of the statement in his own words](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/iauURkH3-for-once-lets-blame-ghostcrawler-for-something-hes-actually-responsible-for?comment=000800000001) (I don't know where the original is).

> ''You don't need to play the game in order to design it'' Look, the people who build airplanes rarely pilot them, but they still have a pretty good idea of how one flies a plane. That's all I was saying. That quote (taken out of context as these things sometimes are) was in response to the persistent yet somewhat tired theory that the best players should be the ones to design competitive games. There are some players who are excellent designers (and we hire some of them), and there are other players who would be dreadful at the job. If you don't play the game you design, it will definitely be much, much harder for you to be effective, but yes, in a theoretical sense, it is possible.

Yea, Vel is just one of many examples. Riot's 'balance' for bad performing champs seems always to be 'increase damage numbers' and that's it.
Olaf for example, that increased AS will either bring his clearspeeds, which are already his strong side, to obnoxious levels, oer it will achive nothing at all. His issue is that he's usless in teamfights cause he explodes befor doing a single AA, yet they refuse to make his ult finally NOT loose the defstats on use but rather slap more dps that he can't really use onto him.
Fizz needed a bit help after the changes, but not in form of more burst, yet all riot does is throwing some heavy numbers onto his upfront damage, probably leading to huge banrates on him...
I think the problem is that now you have all this mobility that imobile champions are simply useless. He probably needs a new passive to bounce like a ball from spot to spot on the map to keep up.

The meta has 2 issues:

* Insane burst damage
* High mobility

Champions like {{champion:103}} {{champion:245}} {{champion:105}} {{champion:55}} {{champion:7}} {{champion:91}} {{champion:157}} {{champion:238}} {{champion:142}} dominate mid with insane damage and mobility. Surviving damage is one thing - one issue that Meddler already announced to be tackled, but that doesn't solve {{champion:161}}'s core issues: In response to the damage and as an overall trend champions have gotten more mobility in order to completely avoid damage. Just look at {{champion:266}} with multi short CD dashes. That's without considering that players at diamond+ can easily sidestep a lot of {{champion:161}} 's abilities.


**Increasing the scaling on Vel Koz' Q only means that even if Riot fixes the instagib meta - Vel Koz will become overbearing against immobile champions as his damage output already is high, but will see 0 improvements against any of the enemies listed above.**


Thus I suggest to undo the Q-scaling buff and add "grounded" to his W - similar to Cassiopeia's W. It disables dashes and forces enemies to actively sidestep his abilities instead of pressing their "out of jail"-cards.

* This makes counterplay against him more sidestep / movement mechanic / precision (instead of purely reaction) based
* Grants him an opportunity to punish otherwise nonpunishable champions
* He might actually see competitive play as a tactical pick for jungle corridor control.

I love this idea. 
Adding "silent" to W may be a bit too much, but still acceptable for me, since W has telegraph time that not too hard to dodge.
They re looking at damage. Once assassin dmg will be be nerfed, it'll leave room for champion  like velkoz to become playable... Hopefully.
